meta.source: Derived from project identity — no formal brand kit exists
meta.author: Superorganism

colorHarmony.rationale: Slate + blue foundation: technical credibility without corporate coldness. Amber accent for callouts and gate indicators. Green for success states. High contrast for readability on projected screens.

headings.weight: 700 (bold) for slide titles, 600 (semibold) for section headers
headings.style: Clean, geometric, high x-height for projection readability

code.usage: Code snippets, file paths, tool names, terminal output

typography.rationale: Inter is the de facto developer tool typeface — clean, neutral, excellent at small and large sizes. Monospace for anything code-adjacent reinforces the technical identity.

shapeLanguage.corners: Rounded (6-8px radius) — approachable but not playful
shapeLanguage.containers: Cards with subtle borders (#E2E8F0) and light shadows, not hard boxes
shapeLanguage.dividers: Thin horizontal rules or whitespace, not heavy lines
shapeLanguage.icons: Lucide icon set (already used in dashboard) — thin stroke, consistent sizing
shapeLanguage.rationale: Rounded shapes soften the technical density. Cards create visual hierarchy without overwhelming structure.

spatialComposition.grid: 12-column with generous margins (min 10% side margins for projection)
spatialComposition.alignment: Left-aligned text, centered diagrams and large callouts
spatialComposition.density: Low — max 6 bullet points per slide, max 40 words per bullet zone
spatialComposition.whitespace: Generous. 30-40% of each slide should be whitespace.
spatialComposition.rationale: 15-minute talk to 6 people in a room. Low density = higher retention. Whitespace signals confidence.

imagery.style: Diagrams and architecture visuals — no stock photos
imagery.diagrams: ASCII-art-to-SVG conversions of the system architecture, loop flow, memory hierarchy
imagery.charts: Minimal — one comparison table slide, possibly one before/after visual
imagery.photos: None. This is a developer tool presentation, not a marketing deck.
imagery.codeBlocks: Dark background (#1E293B) with syntax highlighting for any code/config shown
imagery.rationale: Engineers trust diagrams and code. Stock photos signal 'marketing deck' which erodes credibility with this audience.

motion.transitions: None or simple fade (0.3s). No slide animations.
motion.builds: Progressive reveal only if a slide has a sequence to walk through
motion.rationale: Animations in a 15-minute technical talk feel like filler. Simplicity signals respect for the audience's time.

voice.person: First person plural ('we built', 'here's what we found') or direct address ('your team', 'your workflows')
voice.jargon: Allowed: MCP, CI/CD, ADR, SSE, Git, TypeScript. Avoided: 'paradigm shift', 'synergy', 'best-in-class', 'leverage'.

tone.primary: Honest and grounded. Acknowledge alpha status. Show the real thing, not a polished pitch.
tone.secondary: Quietly confident. The architecture speaks for itself. No hard sell.
tone.energy: Measured. Not excited/breathless. Not dry/academic. Just clear.

complexity.level: Mid-high. Audience is technical. Don't oversimplify, but don't dump architecture diagrams without context.
complexity.abstractions: Lead with the problem, show the concept, then show the concrete implementation
complexity.numbers: Use specific numbers (38 skills, 10 phases, 105+ tools) — precision builds credibility

pace.opening: Start with the problem they feel. No 'about us' slide. No agenda slide.
pace.development: Problem → concept → concrete demo walkthrough → architecture → adoption path
pace.closing: Honest assessment (what works, what's early), then invite questions / live demo
pace.slidePace: ~80 seconds per slide for 12 slides in 15 minutes. Some slides faster (transitions), some slower (architecture).

persuasion.strategy: Show, don't tell. Let the architecture and specifics do the convincing.
persuasion.proofPoints: Concrete: 38 skills with real names, 10-phase loop with real gates, actual TypeScript code
persuasion.objectionHandling: Pre-empt 'what's the catch' with an honest limitations slide before Q&A
persuasion.callToAction: Soft: 'Want to run the engineering loop on a real feature together? We can do that now.'

storyArc.act1_hook: Your engineering practices are scattered across wikis, heads, and CI configs. What if they were composable, versioned, and self-improving?
storyArc.act2_journey: Here's what that looks like: skills, loops, gates, memory. Walk through a real engineering loop execution.
storyArc.act3_resolution: This is alpha software. Here's what works, what's early, and what adoption looks like. Let's try it.

derivationNote: No formal brand kit. Identity derived from: project name ('Orchestrator' implies precision, coordination), org name ('Superorganism' implies collective intelligence), tech stack (TypeScript/Node signals modern pragmatism), audience profile (DevEx engineers who value substance over style), and presentation context (small room, 15 minutes, evaluation meeting — not a keynote).
